Apple Scab.Explanation: Apple scab is caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis. It affects leaves, fruit, and sometimes young twigs, leading to unsightly, scabby lesions on the fruit.
Artificial Treatment: Use fungicides such as captan, mancozeb, or myclobutanil. Apply at regular intervals starting from the green tip stage until the fruit is harvested.
Systemic fungicides can also be effective and provide longer protection.
Organic Treatment: Apply sulfur or lime sulfur sprays during the growing season.
Implement good sanitation practices, such as removing fallen leaves and pruning infected twigs to reduce inoculum sources.

Grape Black Rot.Explanation: Grape black rot is caused by the fungus Guignardia bidwellii. It affects all green parts of the vine, resulting in black lesions and mummified berries.
Artificial Treatment: Use fungicides like myclobutanil, mancozeb, or azoxystrobin, starting in the early growing season and continuing at 10-14 day intervals until veraison.
Ensure thorough coverage of all plant parts.
Organic Treatment: Practice good vineyard sanitation, such as removing mummified berries and pruning infected plant parts.

Potato Late Blight.Explanation: Late blight in potatoes is caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans. It leads to brown, water-soaked lesions on leaves and tubers, which can cause significant yield loss.
Artificial Treatment: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or metalaxyl at the first sign of disease and continue as recommended.
Organic Treatment: Apply copper-based fungicides as a preventative measure.
Practice crop rotation and plant disease-free seed potatoes.
Remove and destroy infected plant debris.

Tomato Septoria Leaf Spot.Explanation: Septoria leaf spot, caused by Septoria lycopersici, affects tomato plants by creating small, dark spots with gray centers on the leaves, leading to defoliation and reduced yields.
Artificial Treatment: Use fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb, applied at regular intervals starting from the first sign of disease.
Ensure proper plant spacing for good air circulation.
Organic Treatment: Apply copper-based fungicides as a preventive measure.
Remove and destroy infected leaves to reduce inoculum.
Mulch to prevent soil splash and practice crop rotation.

Corn (Maize) Northern Leaf Blight.Explanation: Northern leaf blight is caused by the fungus Exserohilum turcicum. It produces long, gray-green lesions on the leaves, which can reduce photosynthesis and yield.
Artificial Treatment: Apply fungicides like azoxystrobin or propiconazole at the first sign of disease and repeat as necessary.
Organic Treatment: Apply neem oil or compost teas to boost plant health.
Rotate crops and practice good field sanitation.

Peach Bacterial Spot.Explanation: Bacterial spot on peaches is caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. pruni. It results in small, dark, water-soaked spots on leaves, fruit, and twigs.
Artificial Treatment: Use bactericides containing copper or oxytetracycline, starting at bloom and continuing at regular intervals.
Ensure proper tree spacing and pruning for good air circulation.
Organic Treatment: Apply copper-based sprays as a preventative measure.
Implement good sanitation practices, such as removing infected plant parts and avoiding overhead irrigation.
